In a series of project since her first book which explored the ways in which American Jewish engaged with the issues surrounding the condition of black Americans in the early twentieth century through her most recently published book which examined the ways in which Jews in post-World War II America went about the process of creating a public culture which memorialized the Holocaust she has been interested on the mutual impact of America and the Jews. She has ventured out from there looking in several books at the histories of other European immigrant groups in the United States and is currently completing a book on global Jewish migrations and the history of Jewish peddling, a project which takes her far afield from the United States. NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > People > Abby Bender             Abby Bender     Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies   Ph.D. Princeton University; M.A. Princeton University; B.A. Vassar College       Office Address:   1 Washington Mews  New York, NY 10003   Office Hours:   Mondays and Wednesdays 10:30 - 11:15am   Email:        Phone:   212-998-3950   Fax:   212-995-4373       Areas of Research/Interest:   19th and 20th Century British and Irish Literature; James Joyce; Modernism and Empire; The Irish Literary Revival       Bio   Abby Bender received her Ph.D. in English from Princeton University in 2006. Her research and teaching interests focus on Irish literature and culture in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, with an approach often informed by religious and political history, as well as transnational, postcolonial, and cultural studies. Her book Israelites in Erin: Exodus, Revolution, and the Irish Revival , is published by Syracuse University Press (Fall 2015).      Professor Bender’s other publications include essays on Irish-Mexican solidarity during the Mexican-American War (in Genre: Forms of Discourse and Culture ), Roger Casement’s influence on James Joyce (in the James Joyce Quarterly ), the politics of Lady Gregory’s biblical allusions (in The Princeton Library Chronicle ), and Joyce’s use of Jewish collective memory, and specifically the Passover Haggadah, as a model for Irish national memory in Ulysses (in Memory Ireland Volume 4: Joyce and Cultural Memory ). Professor Bender’s new book project is tentatively titled Nursing the Nation: Breastfeeding in Modern Irish Writing .       Professor Bender has been an invited speaker at The Columbia University Irish Studies Seminar, The James Joyce Summer School in Dublin, The New York Public Library, and the inaugural Memorial Lecture for Professor Barbara Gluck at the Baruch College Jewish Studies Center, CUNY. At NYU, she teaches courses on Irish Drama, James Joyce, Contemporary Irish Fiction, and Women’s Writing in Ireland.      ***      "As in my research, an interest in moments of cultural contact—whether actual or imaginative—motivates my teaching. I arrived in Irish Studies via Modernism, the Bible, and Jewish Studies, and I continue to focus on expressions of transcultural and transnational sympathy and connection. I love how the students and faculty at Glucksman Ireland House are similarly expanding the scope of Irish Studies as a field, through work that is interdisciplinary, cross-cultural, and dynamic.      "I have prized the opportunity to mentor both undergraduates and graduate students on exciting research projects, and many of these projects have found audiences beyond our coursework, at conferences and as expanded M.A. theses, for example. Working individually with students to help them develop their original ideas is perhaps the most rewarding aspect of my job, and at GIH it’s a mode that’s fostered by the intimacy and intensity of seminar-style classes that typically meet in the wonderful space of the house itself."   Selected Works:   Israelites in Erin: Exodus, Revolution, and the Irish Revival (Syracuse: Syracuse University Press, 2015). “The Bloomsday Seder: Joyce and Jewish Memory,” in Memory Ireland Volume 4: Joyce and Cultural Memory , eds. Oona Frawley and Katherine O'Callaghan (Syracuse: Syracuse University Press, 2014).    “The Language of the Outlaw: A Clarification,” a note relating to Roger Casement and Ulysses , James Joyce Quarterly , 44:4 (Summer 2007).    “Lady Gregory’s Bible Lessons: The Deliverer and The Story Brought by Brigit ,” Princeton University Library Chronicle (Special Irish Theater Issue) 68:1-2 (Fall 2006-Winter 2007).    Review of Irish Orientalism: A Literary and Intellectual History by Joseph Lennon, The James Joyce Literary Supplement , 19:1 (Spring 2005).    “Irish-Mexican Solidarity and the San Patricio Battalion Flag,” Genre: Forms of Discourse and Culture 36:3 (Fall/Winter 2003).
